column2: PLEASANT MEADOWS
column3: PLEASANT MEADOWS

column2: Beth was soon able to lie on the study sofa all day, amusing herself with the well-beloved cats at first, and in time with doll's sewing, which had fallen sadly behind-hand.
column3: Beth was soon able to lie on the study sofa all day, amusing herself with the well beloved cats at first, and in time with doll's sewing, which had fallen sadly behind hand.

column2: As Christmas approached, the usual mysteries began to haunt the house, and Jo frequently convulsed the family by proposing utterly impossible or magnificently absurd ceremonies, in honor of this unusually merry Christmas.
column3: As Christmas approached, the usual mysteries began to haunt the house, and Jo frequently convulsed the family by proposing utterly impossible or magnificently absurd ceremonies, in honor of this unusually merry Christmas.

column2: The Unquenchables had done their best to be worthy of the name, for like elves they had worked by night and conjured up a comical surprise.
column3: The Unquenchables had done their best to be worthy of the name, for like elves they had worked by night and conjured up a comical surprise.

column2: Out in the garden stood a stately snow maiden, crowned with holly, bearing a basket of fruit and flowers in one hand, a great roll of music in the other, a perfect rainbow of an Afghan round her chilly shoulders, and a Christmas carol issuing from her lips on a pink paper streamer.
column3: Out in the garden stood a stately snow maiden, crowned with holly, bearing a basket of fruit and flowers in one hand, a great roll of music in the other, a perfect rainbow of an Afghan round her chilly shoulders, and a Christmas carol issuing from her lips on a pink paper streamer.

column2: THE JUNGFRAU TO BETH
column3: THE JUNGFRAU TO BETH

column2: Accept a ribbon red, I beg, For Madam Purrer's tail, And ice cream made by lovely Peg, A Mont Blanc in a pail.
column3: Accept a ribbon red, I beg, For Madam Purrer's tail, And ice cream made by lovely Peg, A Mont Blanc in a pail.

column2: Their dearest love my makers laid Within my breast of snow. Accept it, and the Alpine maid, From Laurie and from Jo.
column3: Their dearest love my makers laid Within my breast of snow. Accept it, and the Alpine maid, From Laurie and from Jo.

column2: How Beth laughed when she saw it, how Laurie ran up and down to bring in the gifts, and what ridiculous speeches Jo made as she presented them.
column3: How Beth laughed when she saw it, how Laurie ran up and down to bring in the gifts, and what ridiculous speeches Jo made as she presented them.

column2: I'm so full of happiness, that if Father was only here, I couldn't hold one drop more, said Beth, quite sighing with contentment as Jo carried her off to the study to rest after the excitement, and to refresh herself with some of the delicious grapes the 'Jungfrau' had sent her.
column3: I'm so full of happiness, that if Father was only here, I couldn't hold one drop more, said Beth, quite sighing with contentment as Jo carried her off to the study to rest after the excitement, and to refresh herself with some of the delicious grapes the 'Jungfrau' had sent her.

column2: I'm sure I am, echoed Amy, poring over the engraved copy of the Madonna and Child, which her mother had given her in a pretty frame.
column3: I'm sure I am, echoed Amy, poring over the engraved copy of the Madonna and Child, which her mother had given her in a pretty frame.

column2: Of course I am! cried Meg, smoothing the silvery folds of her first silk dress, for Mr. Laurence had insisted on giving it.
column3: Of course I am! cried Meg, smoothing the silvery folds of her first silk dress, for mr Laurence had insisted on giving it.

column2: Half an hour after everyone had said they were so happy they could only hold one drop more, the drop came.
column3: Half an hour after everyone had said they were so happy they could only hold one drop more, the drop came.

column2: Mrs. March was the first to recover herself, and held up her hand with a warning, "Hush! Remember Beth."
column3: mrs March was the first to recover herself, and held up her hand with a warning, "Hush! Remember Beth."

column2: But it was too late.
column3: But it was too late.

column2: The study door flew open, the little red wrapper appeared on the threshold, joy put strength into the feeble limbs, and Beth ran straight into her father's arms.
column3: The study door flew open, the little red wrapper appeared on the threshold, joy put strength into the feeble limbs, and Beth ran straight into her father's arms.

column2: It was not at all romantic, but a hearty laugh set everybody straight again, for Hannah was discovered behind the door, sobbing over the fat turkey, which she had forgotten to put down when she rushed up from the kitchen.
column3: It was not at all romantic, but a hearty laugh set everybody straight again, for Hannah was discovered behind the door, sobbing over the fat turkey, which she had forgotten to put down when she rushed up from the kitchen.

column2: As the laugh subsided, Mrs. March began to thank Mr. Brooke for his faithful care of her husband, at which Mr. Brooke suddenly remembered that Mr. March needed rest, and seizing Laurie, he precipitately retired.
column3: As the laugh subsided, mrs March began to thank mr Brooke for his faithful care of her husband, at which mr Brooke suddenly remembered that mr March needed rest, and seizing Laurie, he precipitately retired.

column2: Then the two invalids were ordered to repose, which they did, by both sitting in one big chair and talking hard.
column3: Then the two invalids were ordered to repose, which they did, by both sitting in one big chair and talking hard.

column2: Mr. March told how he had longed to surprise them, and how, when the fine weather came, he had been allowed by his doctor to take advantage of it, how devoted Brooke had been, and how he was altogether a most estimable and upright young man.
column3: mr March told how he had longed to surprise them, and how, when the fine weather came, he had been allowed by his doctor to take advantage of it, how devoted Brooke had been, and how he was altogether a most estimable and upright young man.

column2: Jo saw and understood the look, and she stalked grimly away to get wine and beef tea, muttering to herself as she slammed the door, "I hate estimable young men with brown eyes!"
column3: Jo saw and understood the look, and she stalked grimly away to get wine and beef tea, muttering to herself as she slammed the door, "I hate estimable young men with brown eyes!"

column2: The fat turkey was a sight to behold, when Hannah sent him up, stuffed, browned, and decorated.
column3: The fat turkey was a sight to behold, when Hannah sent him up, stuffed, browned, and decorated.

column2: Mr. Laurence and his grandson dined with them, also Mr. Brooke, at whom Jo glowered darkly, to Laurie's infinite amusement.
column3: mr Laurence and his grandson dined with them, also mr Brooke, at whom Jo glowered darkly, to Laurie's infinite amusement.

column2: Two easy chairs stood side by side at the head of the table, in which sat Beth and her father, feasting modestly on chicken and a little fruit.
column3: Two easy chairs stood side by side at the head of the table, in which sat Beth and her father, feasting modestly on chicken and a little fruit.

column2: A sleigh ride had been planned, but the girls would not leave their father, so the guests departed early, and as twilight gathered, the happy family sat together round the fire.
column3: A sleigh ride had been planned, but the girls would not leave their father, so the guests departed early, and as twilight gathered, the happy family sat together round the fire.

column2: Just a year ago we were groaning over the dismal Christmas we expected to have.	Just a year ago we were groaning over the dismal Christmas we expected to have.
Do you remember?" asked Jo, breaking a short pause which had followed a long conversation about many things.
column3: Do you remember?" asked Jo, breaking a short pause which had followed a long conversation about many things.

column2: Rather a pleasant year on the whole! said Meg, smiling at the fire, and congratulating herself on having treated Mr. Brooke with dignity.
column3: Rather a pleasant year on the whole! said Meg, smiling at the fire, and congratulating herself on having treated mr Brooke with dignity.

column2: I'm glad it's over, because we've got you back, whispered Beth, who sat on her father's knee.
column3: I'm glad it's over, because we've got you back, whispered Beth, who sat on her father's knee.

column2: But you have got on bravely, and I think the burdens are in a fair way to tumble off very soon," said Mr. March, looking with fatherly satisfaction at the four young faces gathered round him.
column3: But you have got on bravely, and I think the burdens are in a fair way to tumble off very soon," said mr March, looking with fatherly satisfaction at the four young faces gathered round him.

column2: How do you know?	How do you know?
Did Mother tell you?" asked Jo.
column3: Did Mother tell you?" asked Jo.

column2: Not much.	Not much.
Straws show which way the wind blows, and I've made several discoveries today."
column3: Straws show which way the wind blows, and I've made several discoveries today."

column2: A burnt offering has been made to vanity, this hardened palm has earned something better than blisters, and I'm sure the sewing done by these pricked fingers will last a long time, so much good will went into the stitches.
column3: A burnt offering has been made to vanity, this hardened palm has earned something better than blisters, and I'm sure the sewing done by these pricked fingers will last a long time, so much good will went into the stitches.

column2: I'm proud to shake this good, industrious little hand, and hope I shall not soon be asked to give it away."
column3: I'm proud to shake this good, industrious little hand, and hope I shall not soon be asked to give it away."

column2: If Meg had wanted a reward for hours of patient labor, she received it in the hearty pressure of her father's hand and the approving smile he gave her.
column3: If Meg had wanted a reward for hours of patient labor, she received it in the hearty pressure of her father's hand and the approving smile he gave her.

column2: What about Jo?	What about Jo?
Her face is rather thin and pale just now, with watching and anxiety, but I like to look at it, for it has grown gentler, and her voice is lower.
column3: Her face is rather thin and pale just now, with watching and anxiety, but I like to look at it, for it has grown gentler, and her voice is lower.

column2: She doesn't bounce, but moves quietly, and takes care of a certain little person in a motherly way which delights me.
column3: She doesn't bounce, but moves quietly, and takes care of a certain little person in a motherly way which delights me.

column2: I rather miss my wild girl, but if I get a strong, helpful, tenderhearted woman in her place, I shall feel quite satisfied.
column3: I rather miss my wild girl, but if I get a strong, helpful, tenderhearted woman in her place, I shall feel quite satisfied.

column2: Jo's keen eyes were rather dim for a minute, and her thin face grew rosy in the firelight as she received her father's praise, feeling that she did deserve a portion of it.
column3: Jo's keen eyes were rather dim for a minute, and her thin face grew rosy in the firelight as she received her father's praise, feeling that she did deserve a portion of it.

column2: Now, Beth, said Amy, longing for her turn, but ready to wait.
column3: Now, Beth, said Amy, longing for her turn, but ready to wait.

column2: But recollecting how nearly he had lost her, he held her close, saying tenderly, with her cheek against his own, "I've got you safe, my Beth, and I'll keep you so, please God."
column3: But recollecting how nearly he had lost her, he held her close, saying tenderly, with her cheek against his own, "I've got you safe, my Beth, and I'll keep you so, please God."

column2: I observed that Amy took drumsticks at dinner, ran errands for her mother all the afternoon, gave Meg her place tonight, and has waited on every one with patience and good humor.	I observed that Amy took drumsticks at dinner, ran errands for her mother all the afternoon, gave Meg her place tonight, and has waited on every one with patience and good humor.
I made the music for Father, because he likes the verses."
column3: I made the music for Father, because he likes the verses."
